conclusion: The problem involves determining whether a coach bus traveling at a constant speed can stop in time to avoid hitting a puppy after the driver applies the brakes.
Given data includes initial velocity (20 m/s), initial distance to the puppy (45 m), reaction time (0.5 s), and the velocity-time graph showing constant velocity followed by uniform deceleration.
The velocity-time graph shows the bus maintaining a velocity of 20 m/s for the first 0.5 seconds, then decelerating uniformly to 0 m/s at approximately 5.0 seconds.
The bus maintains a constant velocity of 20 m/s for the first 0.5 seconds due to the reaction time.
The deceleration phase starts after 0.5 seconds and lasts until approximately 5.0 seconds, giving a deceleration time of 4.5 seconds.
The distance traveled during the reaction time is calculated as d1 = v * Δt = 20 m/s * 0.5 s = 10 m.
The deceleration rate is calculated as a = (Δv) / t = (0 - 20) / 4.5 = -4.44 m/s².
The distance traveled during deceleration is calculated using the formula d2 = v_i * t + (1/2) * a * t², resulting in d2 = 20 * 4.5 + (1/2) * (-4.44) * (4.5)² = 45 m.
The total distance traveled by the bus is calculated as d_total = d1 + d2 = 10 m + 45 m = 55 m.
The total distance traveled by the bus (55 m) is greater than the initial distance to the puppy (45 m), so the bus will not stop in time.
The puppy is not safe because the bus travels a greater distance than the initial distance to the puppy.
The area under the velocity-time graph, representing the total distance traveled, confirms the calculation of 55 m.
